newsitem.title: CHINA: China Internet firm buys Microsoft platform.
newsitem.headline: China Internet firm buys Microsoft platform.

text.p: U.S. software giant Microsoft Corp on Friday signed a deal to supply an Internet platform to a Chinese on-line firm, with company officials predicting a rapid growth of Chinese Internet surfers in coming years.

China Infohighway Communications Co Ltd (IHW) had tested the Microsoft Commercial Internet Services (MCIS) platform for about three months before formally signing the deal, Infohighway president Zhang Shuxin said.
Officials declined to say how much the deal was worth.
"Our goal is to generate an open, interactive Chinese cyberspace which the general public in China can enter for work, study, entertainment and shopping," Zhang said.

The deal was Microsoft's first sale of the MCIS platform in China and five or six other Chinese firms had inquired about purchasing the system, said Jia-bin Duh, president of Microsoft (China) Co Ltd.
Demand for Internet services in China would grow along with the rapidly swelling ranks of computer users, Duh said.
Sales of personal computers in China were about 2.5 million units in 1996 and that figure was expected to rise to more than three million in 1997, Duh said.
"Wherever there is a telephone jack, there is a possibility that they will become an Internet user," he said. China says it has 100,000 Internet users.
Microsoft would also provide consulting and support services to IHW and copies of IHW's Internet start-up software would be included in Microsoft's Chinese-language version of Windows 95, Zhang said.
IHW had about 10,000 customers nationwide, about half of whom were individuals, Zhang said, adding that she expected that number to grow rapidly.
Set up in 1995, IWH had nodes in eight Chinese cities and was the first Internet provider to supply on-line services such as electronic mail, information retrieval and news in Chinese, Zhang said.
The firm, 74 percent state-owned, had a registered capital of 80 million yuan ($9.64 million). IHW's revenue was expected to hit about 100 million this year, Zhang said.
